story: Inch Cape Offshore Ltd has been given approval to site the building ndash which will bring energy ashore from an offshore wind farm ndash on land at the former Cockenzie Power Station by Scottish Ministers.A planning application was initially lodged with East Lothian Council but was called in by the Scottish Government before a decision was made.That decision sparked anger after it was announced as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was on an official visit to China, where she met representatives of Chinese state owned Red Rock, which owns Inch Cape.Now the company has presented a revised plan of the space it intends to use to Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council.The community council posted the new design on social media and revealed plans were under way for Inch Cape to host workshops in the local communities in the coming months.The image shows the substation on about a third of the original .-hectare footprint applied for.One of the biggest concerns raised by communities and the local authority, which owns the land, was that a substation dominating the old power station site would make it a no-go area for other developments.The new plans were welcomed by many on the community councilrsquos Facebook page, with one person saying: ldquoGood news, less sterilisation of the site.Ian Johnson, Inch Capersquos project manager, said: ldquoWe are continuing to engage with East Lothian Council and local community councils on options to signicantly reduce the footprint of the onshore transmission works and moving this to the west of the site.ldquoWhile this detailed design plan is subject to further technical assessments, consultation and approval from the council, we are taking steps to ensure remaining land is available for other developments.

title: east-lothian-school-pupils-to-take-part-in-strike-against-climate-change
story: The NBHS Eco Committee have encouraged students to travel by public transport to attend the rally campaigning for stronger government action to combat climate change.The Edinburgh protest is one of many around the world that are happening tomorrow morning, where school children are walking out of classes to protest climate change.The protest starts at am outside the Scottish Parliament.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe want to support our young people as global citizens to have their voice and to be able to express their views on important matters such as climate change."The safety and wellbeing of our young people is of paramount importance to us. We would therefore ask that any young person who wishes to attend this event first discusses it with their parent or carer before notying the headteacher of the intention to be absent from school on this date."Given that the young person will not be on school premises at this time, and therefore not the responsibility of school staff, they will be marked as having had an unauthorised absence.

title: three-hour-jumpathon-for-red-nose-day-at-musselburgh-trampoline-park
story: The team at Jump In in Newhailes Industrial Estate will need to have a real spring in their step when they don their pyjamas to take part in a national -hour Jumpathon relay with the companyrsquos seven other UK sites.Theyrsquore inviting more jumpers to join them for their three-hour session in aid of Comic Relief between pm and pm tomorrow .There will be the chance to donate on the day or those who canrsquot attend but would still like to show their support can visit justgiving fundraising jump-inGareth Trail, regional manager for Jump In, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be involved in Red Nose Day, raising money for so many special causes.ldquoWe would love to see as many people as possible down here on the day showing their support to our staff, who will be jumping for three hours non-stop.Other attractions on the day will include face-painting, a cake sale and raffle with a hamper full of Jump In goodies up for grabs.

title: cockenzie-and-port-seton-gala-saved
story: The galas organising committee had announced on Monday evening that this years gala had been cancelled due to a lack of volunteers.But an outpouring of support on social media caused an emergency meeting to be held yesterday eveningto consider the future of the gala.And following that meeting, the gala committee posted on Facebook: ldquoWe would like to give a big thank you to all who attended the EGMtonight."We are thrilled to announce that we are now in a position to go ahead with the  gala.Full steam ahead!Cockenzie and Port Seton Gala celebrated its th anniversary last year and is one of the largest galas in East Lothian.

title: tranents-redeveloped-former-co-op-building-getting-ready-to-re-open
story: The building on Winton Place is being converted into a Post Office, convenience store and coffee shop by well-known local couple George and SusanThomson.ldquoWe want to expand the business but we also want a nice place for people in the community to go and socialise, said George. ldquoWe want to draw people to the High Street.ldquoWersquove ran the Post Office in Tranent for over  years now, added Susan. ldquoWersquore really involved with the community, so this project was important to us in so many ways.As well as being postmaster, Susanco-founded the Blooming Belters and is the secretary of the townrsquos gala committee.ldquoAlthough wersquore converting a lot of it, it will still be able to host the local groups and charities that make this community so special, she said.The Thomsons worked closely with Historic Scotland to ensure that the Edwardian building retained its original charm, including putting in stained glass windows around the outside of the structure.George said: ldquoThe stained glass windows help make the building look how it would have looked a hundred years ago.ldquoHistoric Environment Scotland had also asked to have a temporary exhibition about the history of shopfronts in the country over the last  years, and there was so much interest in it that wersquove made it into a permanent display.The impressive window display covers all styles of shopfronts in Scotland throughout the century, giving information on the dferent materials used, accompanied by an archive of photos of shops dating back to the late s.ldquoThe work wersquove done with Historic Scotland is a perfect example of a public and private partnership that can maintain and renovate listed buildings, George said.The plans for the building have been in the making since  and Susanrecalled the highs and lows of taking on such project.ldquoItrsquos great finally seeing it all come together, she said. ldquoAt the start itrsquos dficult to see what it will look like and, of course, itrsquos a lot of work. Wersquore excited for it to be open and for people to get to see the finished product. We think itrsquoll be pretty special, especially in the summer when we get the chairs outside and all the flowers are in bloom.The opening in April will mark the end of phase one for the Thomsons.Phase two will involve creating a soft play area and flats above the shop, as well as a community hall.The work on phase two will begin in August, with hopes that the whole project will be completed by .

title: jobs-created-at-former-pinneys-plant-in-annan
story: The factory in Dumfries and Galloway has been purchased by food processing company Bhagat Holdings Limited which said production would begin in the autumn.The area was left devastated when it was announced last year that the Pinneys of Scotland factory was being closed by parent company Youngrsquos.New owners Bhagat said the company is investing pound million of capital funding at the site.It plans to create an initial  jobs and said there is the potential for more in the future.The Scottish Government, through Scottish Enterprise, has invested pound. million through a Regional Selective Assistance grant to support the company to expand its European interests to Scotland.Rural Economy Secretary Fergus Ewing said:ldquoThis is great news for the people of Annan, and for the South of Scotland more generally.ldquoIrsquom delighted that an international company like Bhagat Holdings has chosen to invest in Scotland, with the immediate creation of a signicant number of jobs, which will make a real dference to local people and the local economy.ldquoWhen Youngrsquos closed last summer, I said that we would leave no stone unturned and we would keep working to find a solution and an alternative use for this site.ldquoThat hard work has now paid off and it is Annan and the local community and families who will benefit.Dumfries and Galloway Council leader Cllr Elaine Murray said:ldquoI am very pleased with this announcement and hope it signals an upturn in the regionrsquos economy, following the closure of Pinneys last year.ldquoWe welcome Bhagat Holdings to our region and wish them well in the future.Scottish Secretary David Mundell said: ldquoThe re-opening of the former Pinneys factory and creation of  jobs is very welcome news for Annan and the surrounding area.ldquoPinneysrsquo closure last year hit hard. I saw first-hand the tremendous efforts partners, workers and the whole community made to try and save the site.ldquoI welcome Bhagat Holdings Limitedrsquos arrival and plans to start production in the autumn ndash with the prospect of even more jobs being created in the future.ldquoItrsquos a double boost for the Borderlands coming just a few days after the UK and Scottish governments announced pound million funding to drive economic growth in the region by helping existing business, encouraging new ventures and bringing a wealth of improvements to people who live and work here.Colin Smyth MSP said he was pleased a new owner had been found.He added: ldquoI hope they will be able to grow the workforce once more. However, the numbers of posts being created initially is a fraction of the jobs lost at Pinneys.ldquoThere is still an urgent need for the Scottish Government to invest in the local economy and thatrsquos why I have renewed my call for a proper economic action plan for Annan.ldquoMore needs to be done to grow existing businesses and attract new ones to the area.

title: school-pupils-to-help-sell-special-edition-of-the-big-issue
story: Fteen pupils from four schools visited the charityrsquos editorial headquarters on Glasgowrsquos Bath Street to help create the issue and a social enterprise-inspired supplement.The supplement will be included in all copies of the Scottish edition which will also be sold at a number of schools across the country.Russell Blackman, Big Issue managing director, said he was ldquoexcited the magazine was working with the Social Enterprise Academyto help produce the issue.He said: ldquoIt was brilliant to work so closely with an investee of our social investment arm, Big Issue Invest, in order to offer a truly special run of the magazine for our Scottish readers.ldquoThe magazine has been written, edited and sold by the pupils, a reflection of the pupil-led nature of the schools programme that SEA runs so successfully, which empowers young people to take action about the social issues that matter to them.The Big Issue is available to buy across the UK for pound. with the special edition on sale from March  to .It will also be sold by pupils in  schools in Fe, Glasgow, the Highlands and Islands and West Dunbartonshire.Neil McLean, SEA chief executive, said: ldquoThe schools special magazine is giving Scotlandrsquos young people a  to shout about the issues that they care about, creatively showing how they are solving these issues by running their own sustainable social enterprises.ldquoThrough taking part in Social Enterprise Schools, pupils are empowered to take action and affect real social change in their communities.ldquoAs well as developing key employability and entrepreneurship skills for the future, our young people are inspiring other young people as far away as Australia, to develop socially entrepreneurial solutions to the challenges facing our world today.

title: Scotland s Insider Guide  Banchory
story: The surrounding landscape, meanwhile, is simply spectacular, with hills and glens, forests and rivers, castles and waterfalls galore. Indeed, you can see why Her Majesty isnrsquot the only one tempted back to the area year after year.Historic highlightsSome  miles west of Aberdeen, Banchory is believed to have been founded by ldquoBishop of the Picts St Ternan, a follower of St Ninian, in the fth century.Two early Christian cross-slabs still survive on the site of the townrsquos earliest church.The Burnett of Leys family were influential in the area, having been given land by Robert the Bruce in . They built Crathes Castle in the sixteenth century, which served as the ancestral family home until , when it was given to the National Trust for Scotland.Scotlands Insider Guide: InverurieBanchory grew signicantly in the Victorian era with the coming of the railway in  . These days it remains a popular choice for families, commuters andtourists alike.What to doYoursquoll enjoy exploring Banchoryrsquos handsome, bustling streets with its attractive granite architecture, historic churches and vibrant mix of shops, cafes and hotels.A trip to the excellent Banchory Museum on Bridge Street is a must . Telling the story of Banchory and its people, it is particularly strong on the le and times of James Scott Skinner ndash the Strathspey King ndash fiddler and dancemaster to Queen Victoria. There are also fascinating exhibits on the archaeological wealth of the area and the local contribution to the First World War.Since  the Barn Arts Centrehas been the townrsquos main creative hub.With a great reputation on the folk and traditional scene, it stages regular live music, comedy and drama, as well as film screenings and visual art.Have a mooch about the on-site gallery or visit Buchananrsquos Bistro next door for coffee and cake. You can also wander round the community allotments and wild garden to the rear.The Falls of Feugh on the southern edge of town offer wonderful views all year round, but during February and March, then in September to November, you may be lucky enough to witness the extraordinary natural phenomenon of salmon leaping.Dating back to the mid-th century, historic Crathes Castle and garden is also a mustfor visitors to the town. Inside this Scots baronial masterpiece there are antiques, portraits, painted ceilings and Burnett family heirlooms galore, with some linking back to the days of Robert the Bruce.Outside, meanwhile, the stunning garden and grounds are home to a wonderful array of plants, trees and wildle.Scotlands Insider Guide: InverurieYoursquoll easily spend a whole day at this family-friendly castle, which hosts a full schedule of events throughout the year and has a smashing courtyard cafeacute.Castle open at weekends only till April , then daily. Gardens and cafeacute now open daily. Meanwhile, more adventurous visitors looking to channel their inner Tarzan will enjoy the on-site Go Ape treetop experience .Andone castle isnrsquot enough, just a -minute drive from Crathes is Drum Castle, ancient seat of clan Irvine. Also in the care of the National Trust for Scotland, it recently underwent an impressive renovation. The cosy tearoom is worth a visit in itself.Where to eatThe award-winning Cow Shedbrasserie in Raemoir Road offers local seasonal ingredients cooked with flair and simplicity in lovely surroundings.The Deeside venison with haggis olives is a delight, and the fish and chips are also world-beating, whether eaten in or bought from the Cowshed ldquochipper.The Falls of Feugh Restaurant at Bridge of Feughalso reflects the best of Scotlandrsquos larder, blending local ingredients with a modern, no-fuss approach.The rainbow trout with langoustine bisque and locally foraged wild garlic is an excellent calling card, while the steaks are memorable too.If itrsquos a taste of the Mediterranean yoursquore after, Mamma Mia in Dee Street is the place to be, run by locals Michele Rossetti and Lesia Robertson. Superb pizzas and the best tiramisu in town.The Chatterbox Cafeacute in Dee Street serves up tasty soups, sandwiches and cakes. Anditrsquos a buttery yoursquore after, yoursquove come to the right place. Tease Coffee Bar on the High Street offers an extensive choice of ethical coffee from all over the world. Full selection of teas and hot chocolates, too. And the carrot cake is sensational.Where to shopDeeside Drinks Emporium stocks a fantastic array of wines, whiskies and artisan beers with a focus on the local.Gt shop Copper  Grey on the High Street is full of bright and breezy cards, gts, stationery and jewellery.Keen cooks looking to source the best local ingredients should head to the Banchory Farmerrsquos Market from am till pm on the third Saturday of the month at Bellfield car park.Scotlands Insider Guide: InverurieFoodies will also want to visit Finzean Estate Farm Shop which sells a wide range of fresh vegetables, home-reared beef, Finzean venison and game, local artisan cheeses and home-made preserves.At nearby Milton of Crathes, Milton Art Gallery has work by local artists as well as a fine selection of prints and jewellery.Where to stayBoutique: Award-winning Banchory Lodge sits right on the banks of the Dee and offers a friendly boutique experience from pound a night. The newly renovated rooms are spacious and decadent.Traditional luxury: Four-star Tor-Na-Coille is a classic country house hotel set in beautul grounds, with sweeping views across the Aberdeenshire hills. Rooms from pound a night.Quirky: Shieling Beag is a gorgeous studio apartment for two just a few hundred yards from the town centre, with access to a private garden and wonderful views. From pound a night on AirbnbWhat to do nearbyYou donrsquot have to go far for an evocative insight into ancient Aberdeenshire. Nine Stanes Stone Circle, just three miles from Banchory, has been part of the landscape here for more than  years.The Deeside Railway was a vital transport link for over  years before being closed as part of the notorious Beeching cuts of the s.More recently the line has been revitalised by the Royal Deeside Railway Preservation Society, which offers a traditional ndash and magnicent ndash steam and diesel experience along the River Dee. Go to deeside-railway for details.Cairngorms National Park, the UKrsquos biggest, is just a short drive from Banchory, a stunning natural playground for walkers, climbers, hill runners, cyclists, kayakers, wildle-lovers and photographers of all ages and abilities.Even beach bums will be in their element thanks to the beautul sands at Loch Morlich.In the weeks to come Ill be visiting Portree, Dunkeld and Birnam, and Comrie. Email your recommendations about the best things to do and places to eat, stay and shop, to: marianne.taylor@heraldandtimes.

title: nicola-sturgeon-signals-indyref2-push-before-2021
story: The First Minister told a foreign newspaper not to forget she was ldquoelected on a very clear mandate to have another referendumScotland was dragged out the EU against its will.Askedher government might wait until after  before pressing the UK to grant another vote, she replied: ldquoI wouldnrsquot say that at all.She said she was ldquoas convinced as it is possible to be that,Scotland is given the opportunity to choose again, it will choose independence.Her SNP deputy Keith Brown also said last night that this weekrsquos chaos at Westminster over Brexit may prove the point at which momentum for independence became ldquounstoppable.He said: ldquoThe last few days have proved beyond question that Westminster isnrsquot working for Scotland - the complete meltdown over Brexit has shown that clearer than ever. The UK Parliament is an unstable, undemocratic institution foisting an unwanted Brexit on Scotland.ldquoThe whole Westminster system is broken. Itrsquos time Scotland took our own decisions.The First Minister has repeatedly delayed her long-awaited update on a referendum because of Brexit uncertainty, promising an announcement "in a few weeks" for several months.Ms Sturgeon says she has a ldquotriple lock mandate for a referendum based on SNP wins in the last Holyrood and general elections, and a  vote by MSPs.Her apparent reluctance to use it since SNP reversals at the last election has frustrated parts of the Yes movement, including some of her own MPs.Her mandate comment was made in an unreported interview with Canadarsquos National Post last month in Toronto, a meeting the SNP Government revealed this week after a freedom of information request.Ms Sturgeon was asked where her government would wait until after the  ldquobefore pressing the British Parliament to grant another referendum.She replied: ldquoI wouldnrsquot say that at all. By definition, I havenrsquot come to a view on timing, so by definition I canrsquot really answer. But donrsquot forget the government I lead was elected on a very clear mandate to have another independence referendum in the circumstances that Scotland was to be taken out of the EU against our will. So I wouldnrsquot assume that it will be necessarily be after the next Scottish election.Although the UK government has said it would reject a referendum request, Ms Sturgeon could use a refusal to whip up SNP votes at the  poll.Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said: ldquoThe majority of voters in Scotland donrsquot want a isive second independence referendum for at least ten years.ldquoIt would be an act of extreme recklessness to hold an unwanted and unnecessary second independence referendum. Every single opinion poll for over a year has shown that the people of Scotland know we are stronger together.Scottish LibDem constitutional affairs spokesperson Wendy Chamberlain said: ldquoThe First Minister seems to have missed the fact that people are sick of constitutional upheaval.ldquoThe SNP have clearly learnt nothing from the chaos of Brexit because theyrsquore still as intent as ever on replicating that chaos on an even greater scale.Recent polls have suggested most Scots would prefer independence over any form of Brexit, but also that a majority oppose a referendum within  years.The SNP is due to discuss its economic and currency plans for an independent Scotland at its conference next month.

title: scotland-draw-with-england-after-incredible-comeback
story: Having played for  minutes against Italy, and in limited instalments against Ireland, France and Wales, Scotland went for broke as they trailed - after half an hour yesterday, to pull off an amazing comeback, almost the most incredible international victory in history, but ultimately, restore a great deal of pride in what has been a fractured campaign.All the aspirations ahead of that first game against Italy, and even after that opening Saturday victory, were slowly eroded, leaving us with just one win up until the England game to show for all the trials and tribulations this term. Still, mixing metaphors and managers, in the words of Ally MacLeod in , itrsquoll be fine once we get to the World Cup. It might well bethe final  minutes in west London was anything to pin your hopes on.With France beating Italy and Wales clinching the Grand Slam against the Irish, it effectively turned the Twickenham game in to a dead rubber. Just pride and some old forged rupees to play for. A chance for some exhibition stuff, surely  Yes, but no-one could possibly have predicted the twists and turns that would fill match time.Yesterday began with the match ball being delivered, after a bike run from Stirling to Twickers, by former Scotland captain Rob Wainwright, round the world biker Mark Beaumont, endurance cyclist Russell Ky and a few other on their latest Doddie Gump, on behalf of the My Namersquo Doddie Foundation. A worthy cause, but as England were running in tries for fun during the opening exchanges at the rate of a point per minute, a well-intentioned wrong turning somewhere in the Midlands may have been a better idea. No ball, no game.The day started badly for the Scots and deteriorated. Irsquom not a fan of the tune, but who dictates Flower of Scotland should be played in waltz-time  Take your partners for a St Bernardrsquos.For Scottish football fans, lsquorsquo means so much. Yesterday that was all it took, in seconds, for England to score. Cue lsquoSweet Chariot.rsquo Unfortunately, it was supercharged and had four-wheel drive and rumbled over the Scots in those early battles. Around this time I received a text from a mate. ldquoHeading back in to Richmond and the Orange Tree. Cannae watch this. I hope they had a telly.For when all appeared lost, from somewhere, Scotland managed to pull out a fightback of epic proportions. Guys who had looked lost, suddenly became world -beaters McInally, Maitland, Graham, Russell, Johnson and others, all of them really. We knew Scotland could play like that. We had seen it before. But given how their self-belief must have been steamrollered in that opening quarter, this effort will be written in to Scots rugby,not sporting folklore. But let us not forget how close wersquod come to an absolute disaster yesterday before salvaging self-respect and some much-needed championship points. But what, ultimately, have we achieved this far in to  Before a ball was kicked, passed or dropped in anger, I had upset one or two with my prediction that, at best, Scotland might finish fourth in this yearrsquos Six Nations. My guesstimate actually had a bit of logic behind it. Italy was a given, but we donrsquot win on the road that often, especially in Paris or London, while Ireland and Wales are quitedecent teams, but at Murrayfield, we just might ndash with a decent wind - shade it against one of them.We didnrsquot and fourth became fth, accompanied by a catalogue of excuses not turning pressure in to points, not being accurate or clinical enough, and, not having any luck when it comes to losing key personnel. Letrsquos take that point firstThere has been a steady progression at international level whereby Scotland has built strength and experience in depth, something that on reflection, really wasnrsquot there a decade back, no matter how much we may kid ourselves. However, unlike England and perhaps the French, Scotland still donrsquot have the cover or resource to accommodate a casualty count running in to double figures,not dozens.Even for the layman, the attrition rate during this championship has not gone unnoticed. Five test matches in seven weeks, particularly given the intensity of the international game today, is enough to break bodies. Good job no-one has ever been daft enough to think out loud that five successive weekend Tests could be an option in the future.However, much of Scotlandrsquos woes have been self-imposed. Compared to  months ago, when we looked to score on any play, from any position, over the last few weeks we have collectively just ran up too many blind alleys. Yes, it all fell in to place latterly against England, but be honest, on another day wersquod have been crushed and left humiliated.Instead we werenrsquot, instead we left with a touch of optimism, and instead of pain, we left with that ancient silver pot, the Calcutta Cup.Moving pictures of Scotlandrsquos last victory at Twickenham are not quite in monochrome, more a slightly washed-out colour. The video tape should last a few more years before it breaks down to dust, through age. However, after our near- disintegration yesterday, we still live with the prospect of that historic recording decaying before we win again.Better teams than the one eventually selected by Gregor Townsend have biennially headed south, more in hope than honest belief in search of that illusive victory. In two years time, at least we will travel with signicantly more optimism, evenit is  years, and counting hellip

title: paul-hutcheon-brexit-is-a-tragic-plot-line-in-a-tory-soap-opera
story: IT has become an almost a cliche to pay tribute to the Prime Ministerrsquos resilience while simultaneously deriding her lack of political nous.She is stubborn and dogged, her supporters say. She never gives up. She hung around to clear up the Brexit mess left by her awful predecessor. Only a hard heart could disagree with this analysis.Theresa May also deserves a degree of sympathy for her decision to push for a general election in . Almost every commentator, it should be recalled, believed she would rout Jeremy Corbyn and lay the path for a Brexit deal. The fault lay in the hapless campaign she led, not in the triggering of an election.Nearly two years later, May is the central character in a Westminster horror story. No matter how she rolls the dice, no majority appears to exist for any form of Brexit. She is bringing back her draft withdrawal agreement this week, but she is in need of a political miracle.This is where personal sympathy ends and political blame can rightly be aimed in her direction. May, and nobody , is the architect of a Brexit impasse that could see the UK crash out of the European Union without a deal. MPs ldquovoted against this outcome last week, but only EU member states can grant an extension to Article . The EU can name its price.Mayrsquos historic blunder was in laying out a series of Brexit ldquored lines at her partyrsquos conference in . Showing off in front of the Tory faithful, she ruled out the UK staying in either the customs union or the single market, which at a stroke necessitated the creation of the hated Northern Ireland backstop. Withdrawing the UK from the scope of the European Court of Justice - a May obsession from her days at the Home Office - was also written in blood.Her rigid approach may have drawn applause from hundreds of elderly Tories in the conference hall, but the red lines made it impossible for Labour, the SNP or the Lib Dems to support her Brexit plan. She put herself at the mercy of right-wing colleagues in European Research Group and the Democratic Unionist Party. The ideologues were given a veto.Mayrsquos mistake was in forgetting her partyrsquos history. In , John Major was challenged for the leadership by Cabinet colleague John Redwood, whose campaign was motivated by hostility to the EU. A photograph of his supporters from that period is a historical curiosity. It shows a small band of hardliners - people like the late Teddy Taylor and Teresa Gorman - who could not compromise on their loathing of the EU. This grouplet is now a large faction and is blocking Mayrsquos deal. She has allowed herself to be captured by the ERG and held hostage.Brexit is consuming the nation, but the UKrsquos departure from the EU is a tragic plot line in a Tory soap opera. David Cameron committed his party to a referendum in a bid to appease his right wing and stop the rise of UKIP. He refrained from ldquoblue on blue attacks during the campaign for fear of splitting the Conservatives. From beginning to end, Cameron was concerned about party management. May has copied this insular strategy.Her flawed approach brings two options into focus this week. The first is for her ERG tormentors to back her deal, which would be followed by a short extension to Article . Few people expect the militants to turn into eleventh-hour pragmatists. The second option is, on the back of her deal being rejected for a third time, to ask the EU for a much ier delay.Such an outcome would present a huge opportunity for a Prime Minister who was concerned with bringing the country together, rather than healing her partyrsquos wounds. With a yearrsquos breathing room, she could ditch her red lines and hurl the ERG into obscurity. If May backed either a soft Brexit, or a confirmatory vote on her deal, a majority of MPs would follow her.The last thirty years suggest that May will look inwards, not outwards. Europe brought down Thatcher, Major and Cameron. Expect the same obsession to claim a fourth scalp.

title: snp-government-sympathetic-to-fresh-round-of-european-elections
story: Prime Minister Theresa May warned MPs last week that a y delay would ldquoundoubtedly require voters going to the polls to elect MEPs.However, in a statement to this newspaper, Nicola Sturgeonrsquos Government said it was ldquoconfident elections could be delivered in Scotland and such an outcome is ldquopreferable to Mayrsquos Brexit plan.The Prime Minister faces a pivotal week in the House of Commons as she tries to persuade MPs for the third time to support the draft withdrawal agreement she negotiated with the EU.Her plan has been rejected twice, but Tory sources believe progress has been made in winning over doubters in the Conservatives and in Northern Irelandrsquos Democratic Unionist party.However,the deal is declined, a much ier delay would likely be sought, which could ultimately lead to a softer Brexit or a second referendum.Another complication is that a delay could overlap with the European elections, which are scheduled for May.The UK was expected to leave the EU at the end of this month, and thus no longer have to send MEPs to Brussels, but an Article  extension could necessitate UK-wide participation.Pro-Brexit Tories do not want to have to contest another election for the Brussels parliament, and May last week used this prospect as leverage with Conservative MPs who oppose her plan:ldquoSuch an extension would undoubtedly require the United Kingdom to hold European Parliament elections in May . I do not think that that would be the right outcome, but the House needs to face up to the consequences of the decisions that it has taken.The SNP Government, however, which supports a so-called Peoplersquos Vote, is sympathetic to the European elections taking place.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is calling for the Article  EU withdrawal process to be extended for as long as it takes to enable a second referendum on EU membership to be held.ldquoIn those circumstances, discussions would have to take place with the EU regarding elections for the European Parliament taking place in the UK ndash and we are confident this could be delivered across Scotland.ldquoHolding an election,that was necessary, would clearly be preferable to Scotland being forced out of the EU under the damaging terms of the Prime Ministerrsquos deal or the catastrophe of a lsquono dealrsquo outcome.An SNP insider said the party would contest any poll on an anti-Brexit  and reflect the views of the majority of people north of the border.It is understood the SNPrsquos governing national executive committee has taken steps present a list of candidates, should an election take place.Keith Brown, the SNPrsquos depute leader, said: "Theresa May has made such a hash of Brexit, we started preparations in January. So wersquore all fired up, ready to go."The Scottish Liberal Democrats, another anti-Brexit party, are also in a position to pick candidatesan election arises.Scottish Labour are waiting to seeArticle  is extended before making a decision, while a spokesperson for the Scottish Tories said their ldquoexpectation is that Mayrsquos deal will pass, and so no preparations are being made.Documents circulating among EU ambassadors state the bloc would terminate the UKs membership on July stit has not taken part in European Parliament elections.The draft paper makes clear Britain has to take part in the electionsit wants an extension of more than three months.Meanwhile, May is continuing her efforts to salvage her Brexit deal amid further signs of pressure on her position.Further talks are expected over the coming days with the DUP in the hope that persuading the  Northern Irish MPs to back the deal will help sway scores of Tory Eurosceptics to fall into line.DUP deputy leader Nigel Dodds said y talks on Friday with senior ministers including Chancellor Philip Hammond were "constructive" and there was a "renewed focus" from the Government on addressing their concerns.Dodds said: "We have had a constructive dialogue. Those discussions will continue over the coming period of time."Former Cabinet minister Esther McVey suggested fellow Brexiteers could back Mays "rubbish" deal next week to make sure the UK leaves the EU.She told the BBC: "The element now is that people will have to take a bad deal rather than no deal."It has also emerged that senior Tory MP Nick Boles has quit his local Conservative Association in the face of efforts to deselect him as the candidate for the next election amid rows over Brexit.The former minister, who supports a soft Brexit, told members of Grantham and Stamford Conservative Association he was resigning "with immediate effect" but will continue to "take the Conservative whip at Westminsterit is offered "on acceptable terms", according to a letter.Councillor Martin Hill, vice president of the Grantham and Stamford Conservative Association, told members: "As you are all aware, Nick has been at odds with the local party and the Prime Minister for some time, so this announcement does not come as a complete surprise, but the timing does leave at lot to be desired.Chief Whip Julian Smith said Mr Boles "is a valued member of the Conservative Parliamentary party which I hope will continue to benefit from his ideas and drive".

title: jeremy-corbyn-launches-effort-to-find-a-cross-party-brexit-compromise
story: The Labour leader called for urgent meetings to finda ldquosolution that ends the needless uncertainty and worry caused by Prime Minister Theresa Mayrsquos ldquofailed Brexit negotiations.He said Labourrsquos ldquocredible plans would form the starting point for any discussions, but he was keen to find ldquocommon ground with supporters of other plans.The offer has been extended to SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford, Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable, DUP deputy leader Nigel Dodds, Plaidrsquos Liz Saville Roberts and Green MP Caroline Lucas.Backbench MPs invited for talks with Mr Corbyn and shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer include Labourrsquos Peter Kyle and Phil Wilson, who have put forward a plan for the Commons to allow the Prime Ministerrsquos Brexit deal to go through, subject to a referendum.Senior Labour backbenchers Yvette Cooper, Hilary Benn and Rachel Reeves have also been offered talks, along with Tories Ken Clarke and Nicky Morgan.Invitations have also been sent to Sir Oliver Letwin, Nick Boles, Stephen Kinnock and Lucy Powell ndash the Tory and Labour MPs behind a push for a Norway-style soft Brexit inside the single market with a customs union.Labourrsquos Jack Dromey and Tory former minister Dame Caroline Spelman, who led Commons efforts to reject a no-deal Brexit, have also been offered a meeting.Mr Corbyn said: ldquoLabour has set out credible options as to how we propose to break the deadlock and avoid a disastrous no-deal.ldquoThis includes putting forward an alternative Brexit plan with a permanent customs union, single market deal and dynamic alignment on rights and protections.ldquoWe have also said that we would support a public vote to prevent damaging Brexit proposals being forced on the country.ldquoWe would obviously use that position as a starting point for any discussions, but we would like to hear about the plans you are advocating, and we are keen to seethere is scope to find common ground between our respective proposals and to work together to break the impasse.

title: vince-cable-uses-farewell-conference-speech-to-stress-commitment-to-staying-in-eu
story: Sir Vince, who will step down as Lib Dem leader after the local elections in May, said the party had to continue arguing for the benefits of staying in the European Union as the Brexit debate rages at Westminster.He will use his speech in York on Sunday to accuse Theresa May of putting a higher priority on keeping the Conservative Party together than maintaining peace in Northern Ireland in her efforts to revise the Brexit dealrsquos backstop.Declaring that ldquowe are Remain, he will say: ldquoTo those outside the Westminster bubble, the parliamentary games on Brexit are baffling: a weird combination of snakes and ladders, chess and all-in wrestling.ldquoWhatever happens in the next few weeks of parliamentary twists and turns, we must argue ndash since no-one  can be relied upon to do so ndash that none of the several mutually exclusive versions of Brexit on offer ndash soft or hard ndash are as good as the deal we currently have.Just finished speaking to @LibDems #LDconf rally. Two years ago we coined the phrase #exitfrombrexit. Then it felt like a long shot. Today itrsquos the main threat deployed by the Prime Minister against her own party. And wersquore closer than ever to making it happen.mdash Vince CableMarch , The Prime Ministerrsquos efforts to win over Tory Eurosceptics have focused on attempts to revise the backstop, the measures in the Brexit deal aimed at preventing theof a hard border.ldquoThe intensity of the campaign to remove it speaks volumes about the underlying motives of those who demanded Brexit and now demand a lsquoclear Brexitrsquo. They simply deny our history, which is entwined with that of Ireland.Sir Vince will target Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley for criticism after a series of gaffes.ldquoIt really is quite shocking that this Government is so lacking in talent that it employs a Secretary of State for Northern Ireland who says she doesnrsquot understand sectarian voting patterns and then compounds this public declaration of ignorance with a blatantly and naively one-sided view of the killings in the Troubles, he will say.ldquoMs Bradley has revealed an ugly truth: that peace in Ireland matters less than peace in the Conservative Party.Sir Vince, who clashed repeatedly with Mrs May over immigration policy while they sat around the Cabinet table during the coalition years, will use his speech toto the issue, saying it highlights the ides in British politics.ldquoOur mission to move from survival to success, from protest back to power, takes place in a world where liberal values are under siege and in retreat.ldquoNothing quite defines liberalism like its opposite, illustrated by Theresa Mayrsquos policies on immigration.

title: joanna-blythman-reviews-condita-in-edinburgh
story: Joanna Blythman reviews: Condita in EdinburghCondita Restaurant in Edinburgh#s Salisbury PlaceJoanna Blythman reviews: Condita in EdinburghCondita Restaurant in Edinburgh#s Salisbury PlacePic Gordon TerrisWe leave Condita, almost three hours after we walk in the door, utterly enchanted. My dining partner thinks that this might be one of the very best meals of his le. I meanwhile, a harder nut to crack, have undergone something of a conversion to long, drawn-out tasting menus. This meal slips by like a languorous dream, unfolding pleasure after pleasure.It starts with an exquisite silky-sweet poached mussel, topped by a seaweed emulsion and black pearls of caviar, sitting in an edible shell made from potato and squid ink, a perfect first bite. It gives us the measure of the cooking level here, technically highly accomplished yet anchored by a sympathetic, highly intuitive understanding of the flavour properties and potential of ingredients.From here on in we feel aswersquore being led into an adventure. Not one of those passive eating experiences where yoursquore babied and told to open your mouth so that a waiter can squirt a pipette at a precise point of your soft palate. The mussel earned our consent and won our trust. Now our curiosity is spiked. What next  Haddock, poached in a ldquonage . Itrsquos been lsquosandwichedrsquo between hot salty wafers made from crisp-roasted chicken skin, dressed with vinaigrette made from the nage, topped with cregraveme fraiche. and somehow or other, confit egg yolk has been grated over it. The contrast of the simple fish with the brittle, fatty skin is blissful.: Public House by Nico, Great Western Road, Glasgow. Reviewed by Ron MackennaUp comes the next offering, boned chicken wing, stuffed with smoked eel, and grilled in the Japanese yakitori manner. The blackness of the grill accentuates the smokiness of the eel unctuous grilled skin encases the succulent brown meat. If these were served as canapeacutes it would be a sensational party. Our appetites are standing to attention, begging for more.Now itrsquos time for our own little sourdough loaf. Itrsquos made from a three-year old sourdough starter known as Lazarus because it seemed dead and was revived, and has been fermented for  hours. Its mercury-black crust, when we tackle it, sounds like an iceberg cracking. We anoint it with salty goatrsquos butter.Now wersquove got to the celeriac, treated four ways. Salt-baked slices taste as good as salsy. A very finely cut raw remoulade caps that. The skin has been deep-fried to make crisps. Then therersquos the sauce, creamy and slightly caramelised, the ecru tones of the vegetable brightened by a few dashes of limpid green celery oil.Wersquore so into this meal that we still have space for this extraordinarily tender fillet of salt-aged roe deer, which nestles in amongst mustardy scurvy grass, wild leek, cooling chicory, black pudding pureacutee and crumble, a gravy that tastes like a liquid distillation of roasting pan juices, golden beetroot pureacutee, and slightly acetic mustard seeds.On to a ldquocrossover course bridging savoury and sweet, parsnip, my least favourite vegetable, but it wins me over. Itrsquos a parfait of the vegetable quivering between fragile, emollient cocoa butter layers, with honey foam on top, strewn with honeycomb. All the wild flavours in the honey are captured, harnessed to an amber orangey-ness. Finally dessert, a ball of heavenly Yorkshire rhubarb parfait flanked by a smaller ball of custard encased in white chocolate wrapped in silver leaf, amidst more rhubarb- poached, dried, a gel- and a sensational rosemary crumble.As I said, Condita serves a dream of a meal.Condita,  Salisbury Place, Edinburgh   Food:  Atmosphere:  Value for money: Service:

title: destination-detox-13-of-scotlands-coolest-spas
story: Wersquove put together our list of  coolest spas, so you can choose just where to treat your mum, yourself, or anyone  in need of a proper unwind. Stobo Castle,PeeblesThe fact this spa is located in a castle that has its own helipad speaks volumes about the kind of luxury experience it offers. Last year, this Borders-based hotel was crowned best destination spa at the Good Spa Guide awards.The range of treatments is extensive, including the Neom collection which uses aromatherapy to enhance treatments. The ozone-treated swimming pool is a dream and looks out through giant windows on to the hillside beyond.Buta bit more privacy is what you want, therersquos always a lounge in the private hot tubs, away from it all. Even the ladies loos have their own special technological experience.Spa Day packages start with the pound Relaxing Spa Day, which includes water massage, express facial and lunch. Auchrannie Resort,Brodick, ArranArranrsquos top-notch Auchrannie Resort has an indulgence for everyone ndash even offering a Princess Package in the spa for children. With two swimming pools, a games hall and an adventure activity programme, there is also plenty to distract the kids.Treatments revolve around Espa products and Ishga, a range made from Scottish seaweed harvested in the Outer Hebrides. Stayyou can in one of the woodland lodges, where you can relax in your own wood-fired hot tub while taking in a view of the glen.Packages include Island Escape, offering two -minute treatments at pound, and Island Retreat ndash pound for two -minute treatments selected from a range including full body massage, algae wrap, luxury manicure or pedicure, and signature facial. Dunkeld House Hotel,DunkeldSet in  acres of private grounds in Perthshire, on the banks of the river Tay, Dunkeld House is all about the relaxation with its sauna, steam room, whirlpool bath and heated indoor pool surrounded by views over the Craigvinean Hills.The spa specialises in treatments using products by the Scottish organic seaweed skincare brand, Ishga. Special offer during March is the Made For Le Mindful Moments treatment, priced at pound for  minutes of ldquonurturing meditation combined with ldquofoot ritual, head, neck and shoulder massage, and back massage. Principal Blythswood Square Hotel, GlasgowSpa of the year at The Look Awards , the Principal Blythswood Square Hotel is the destination spa in Glasgow. In the basement of one of Scotlandrsquos most swish hotels it is a hidden gem, complete with hydrotherapy pool, sauna and crystal steam room.If therersquos a treatment you want, itrsquos likely you can get it here ndash from hot stone massages to revitalising body scrubs, and with names to make you swoon even before yoursquove got your robe and slippers on. Among them are Ila Pearl and Jasmine Amethyst Wrap, Ila Rose Bliss Bath or Twilight Thermal Experience. Plus the whole look of the place is to die for ndash black tiles, white spaces, chill relaxation areas.This is for those who can only chill out in the trendiest, most style-forward of environments. Pure, Apex Hotel,#EdinburghRight in the centre of Edinburgh, on the edge of the Old Town, Pure spa has a joint in the Apex hotel, and while itrsquos not huge, itrsquos got everything you might want for a bit of indulgence while enjoying the delights of the capital. It specialises in Elemis anti-ageing facials, as well as heat therapies, massages and scrubs.Its one of a growing chain of Pure spas to be found across the UK.  SVS,GlasgowYou donrsquot get much more stylish than this Art Deco spa on St Vincent Street, right in the heart of Glasgow. Itrsquos the perfect pamper stop-off on a city day out.Treatments are based around Elemis products, aromatherapy and Opi and Shellac manicure.Here you can also try Hopi ear candling or get some party strip lashes done to get you set for a night out on the town. Stables spa,Isle of EriskaOn a small, private island at the mouth of Loch Creran, attached to a Scottish baronial-style house, is the Stables spa, complete with -metre swimming pool, reached by a path through the spa garden. If what you want is proper indulgence then book one of the one-bedroom spa suites and Hilltop Reserve villas with their own hot tubs. The spa offers, it says, ldquofive treatment rooms, three to connect you to the natural land, plants and wood, and two connecting you to the cleansing sea and tranquil shores that surrounds you.Spa day packages include the Rasul Experience ndash pound to sit in your own private mud chamber ndash and the Discover Eriska Spa Package, which includes two -minute treatments and afternoon tea for pound. Portavadie,Loch FyneThe Portavadie development has transformed this not-so-easy-to-reach spot on Loch Fyne into a top destination ndash and the star of it all is the spa, which not only offers a hydro pool, sauna, steam room and a bunch of treatments, but also a stunning heated outdoor infinity pool, the largest in Scotland, that looks out over the loch.The views are part of the thrill even in the sauna and relaxation space, where floor-to-ceiling windows look out on it all ndash you might possibly catch sight of a seal or an otter as you relax. Portavadie has even earned a Green Tourism Gold Award for its use of renewable energies throughout the resort. Day packages include the Harmony Retreat at pound, which includes an Ishga or Decleor treatment. New Lanark Hotel,New Lanark villageOriginally an th-century cotton mill and placed right in the middle of the New Lanark World Heritage site, the New Lanark Hotel offers a spa day that is like chilling in a piece of history. The New Lanark Health and Fitness Club includes a swimming pool, Jacuzzi, steam room, sauna and a health and fitness studio, plus beauty rooms for guests to enjoy a range of customised treatments including candle massage, aromatherapy massage, waxing treatments, manicures and pedicures.Spa day packages available at pound., and residential spa packages from pound per person, including dinner, bed and breakfast and use of the spa. One Spa, Sheraton Grand,EdinburghIf you thought city spas were small and bijou, think again. One Spa is a huge, therapeutic sprawl of  treatment rooms, a -metre pool, relaxation area, steam rooms, saunas and rooftop hydrotherapy pool. All of this on the edge of the city centre, overlooking Edinburgh Castle. It even offers, through the Now By One Spa, express experiences targeting the time-poor, stressed-out urbanite. But the best way to experience it is on a long day package, darting from sauna to pool to chill-out area.The Revival Spa Day , for instance, includes a body massage and facial, plus use of spa for pound. Knock Castle spa,CrieffIn the town of Crieff in rural Perthshire, Knock Castle is a boutique hotel, quirky enough to have its own grand piano in the hallway and offering its own distinct luxury spa experience. Among its pleasures is its heated swimming pool, surrounded by large windows which look out on to the gardens around. But there is also the steam room, the sauna and The Egg, a stress-busting chamber, which was developed by an Aberdeen firm. Inside this eight feet-tall pod, you lie on a contoured massage bed and thus begins a multisensory treatment of lighting, sounds and aromatherapy.Knock Castle also offers a range of treatments, including the Chocolate Experience ndash a -minute massage and paraffin wax treatment, at pound. Fletcherrsquos Cottage at Archerfield House,DirletonDescribed as one of the best UK spa breaks by Vogue magazine, Fletcherrsquos Cottage Spa at Archerfield House in Dirleton is all about the natural, Scandi vibe. There may be no infinity pool in this chilled haven, but it more than compensates with its hygge feel and location.The cottage overlooks an idyllic walled garden, a log burner glows in the relaxation room, and theres a salt steam room and aroma sauna. Inidual treatments include the Signature Treatment, combining massage and stretching, for pound. Old Course Hotel,St AndrewsThe big claim to fame of the Old Course, spa-wise, is that it hosts the only Kohler Waters Spa outside the United States. What this means is that the waters in all these bathing experiences are natural, mineral-rich waters. Itrsquos going back to the old idea of the spa as salus per aquum ndash ldquohealth through water ndash and giving it that modern, luxury kick.Here there are wet treatment rooms, showers featuring Kohler ldquoReal Rain, a hydrotherapy pool and a cold plunge pool.Of course, itrsquos not all about the water ndash there is also an astounding array of other treatments here including peat or seaweed body wraps, a volcanic scrub ritual, a wide range of massages and Margaret Dabbs product manicures.Day packages start from pound, which includes a facial or back massage and a light snack lunch. Round of golf  Nah, just chill in this pool a bit longer.I Should Cocoa: The Treatment TestVicky Allan tries the Chocolate Experience at Knock Castle SpaMotherrsquos Day, which arrives a fortnight today, has long been all about mums putting their feet up and being indulged. But we all know that what many mothers want is not just breakfast in bed, but a whole relaxing day in a fluffy goonie and slippers ndash in other words, a spa package. But which spa to plump for  And should you choose the algae wrap, the hot paraffin experience, or some gentle ear candling Wersquove put together our list of  coolest spas, so you can choose just where to treat your mum, yourself, or anyone  in need of a proper unwind.And remember,you want the chance to win one of SIX amazing luxury pamper breaks, just turn to Page  and enter our fantastic competition.

title: parents-of-a-girl-with-downs-syndrome-say-they-lives-are-enriched
story: ROSIE is busy in the living room, playing on her tablet. Shersquos blissfully unaware of the conversation her parents are having at the kitchen table.The dresser behind Jamie and Victoria McCallum is filled with dozens of birthday cards from Rosiersquos classmates. Shersquos just turned six - but the couple are discussing what le would have been liketheyrsquod terminated the pregnancy. Rosie was born with Downrsquos Syndrome.The McCallums didnrsquot have to confront the idea of termination, however, while Victoria was pregnant. They didnrsquot take any tests. It was only when Rosie was born that they realised she had Downrsquos Syndrome. Victoria wouldnrsquot have terminated, eventests had come back positive. Jamie, though, knowing nothing about the condition then, might have thought dferently.lsquoWe wouldrsquove had a hell of a debate on our hands,rsquo he says. Victoria wonders aloud lsquowhether our relationship would have survivedrsquo. Itrsquos impossible to quanty the joy theyrsquod have lostthere was no Rosie in their lives. Today, knowing the facts about Downrsquos Syndrome, termination would never cross Jamiersquos mind.The McCallums have grown from a family devastated by Downrsquos Syndrome to one enriched by the condition. Jamie, , runs his own management consultancy, and Victoria, , worked in marketing but now raises their children at home. Theyrsquore among the most prominent advocates in Scotlandrsquos Downrsquos Syndrome community, and Rosie is something of a superstar within that world, a child who can count Michael Bubleacute, the singer Christina Perri, and Phillip Schofield and Holly Willoughby among her admirers.Those birthday cards on the dresser - from  children across their home town, Prestwick - tell the story of the changing nature of Downrsquos Syndrome within society. Years ago, there would have been no cards from friends.Every family touched by the condition shudders when they think of the past - of times like the s when children were locked away in institutions, their le chances little more than zero. Today, children with Downrsquos Syndrome are increasingly embraced by society, they look forward to a future where they go to mainstream school, get a job, live independently and fall in love. There are young people with Downrsquos Syndrome embarking on careers in theatre and sport Karen Gaffney, one of the worldrsquos best known people with Downrsquos Syndrome, swam the channel, earned an honorary doctorate, and gave a Ted talk.On Thursday itrsquos the McCallums th wedding anniversary . lsquoClearly le had a path for us,rsquo says Victoria. The family have a message to share, on this week which means so much to them. They fear that just as people with Downrsquos Syndrome are becoming accepted by mainstream society, that they may - in Jamiersquos words - soon be lsquoeradicatedrsquo.Until now, accurate testing for Downrsquos Syndrome centred on an amniocentesis, where a needle draws fluid from the uterus for analysis. Some parents are reluctant to take the test, fearing miscarriage. Now, a new blood test is to be rolled out which can accurately check for Downrsquos Syndrome without risk. The take up is expected to be huge, and the resulting terminations equally high. At the moment, the abortion rate is around  per cent. Scotland has a population of , with  births a year.lsquoIceland rolled [the new testing] out and there hasnrsquot been a Downrsquos Syndrome birth since,rsquo says Jamie. lsquoItrsquos like a government-funded eugenics programme.rsquoThe thought of a world without Rosies horries the McCallums. Both admit to being completely uninformed when Rosie - the middle of their three children - was born. Itrsquos impossible to make an informed choice about termination when all parents know are the long-standing myths - that children wonrsquot be able to dress themselves, or go to the toilet that theyrsquoll be le-long lsquoburdensrsquo, or incapable of learning.Jamie says his view of Downrsquos Syndrome when he was growing up was lsquoa form of prejudice - and prejudice comes from ignorancersquo. He would have seen lsquosomeone who canrsquot possibly be happy as they donrsquot have the faculties of the rest of us, and thatrsquos why itrsquos such a shake-up to your value system when you realise wersquove made all that stuff uprsquo.Victoria is brutally honest but even she struggles to admit that when she was growing up she probably saw people with Downrsquos Syndrome as lsquoretardedrsquo. lsquoThatrsquos a really awful thing to say,rsquo she adds. lsquoI remember feeling sorry for them. They werenrsquot accepted, they always stood on the periphery hellip When I fell pregnant one of my biggest fears was Downrsquos Syndrome.rsquoNevertheless, like many parents, they didnrsquot opt for an amniocentesis as they werenrsquot high risk. It wasnrsquot until moments after Rosiersquos birth that they realised she had Downrsquos Syndrome.lsquoI was shit scared,rsquo says Victoria. She looked at her babyrsquos eyes and lsquojust knewrsquo. Jamie was oblivious. He was holding Rosie - lsquoproud as punchrsquo - and had no idea anything was wrong until Victoria askedhe thought she had Downrsquos Syndrome. Jamie put Rosie down, took his phone to the bathroom and looked for lsquobabies with Downrsquos Syndromersquo on Google images.lsquoI knew at that point,rsquo Jamie says, but his words falter as tears overcome him. Victoria becomes upset at Jamiersquos distress and explains: lsquoItrsquos a post traumatic stress thing. It was a brutal experience.rsquoJamie continues: lsquoI just put her down and I didnrsquot pick her up again for quite some time.rsquo Victoria adds: lsquoI shut off and went into automatic mother mode. I just went lsquoI canrsquot cope with this so what I need to do is look after this babyrsquo - and Irsquod basically say lsquothis thingrsquo as at that time thatrsquos how I felt. Itrsquos brutal but itrsquos true.rsquolsquoYoursquove this path in your mind,rsquo says Jamie, lsquoand all of a sudden your entire future gets reformed - and then pour in all your prejudice, ignorance and misconceptions.rsquoVictoria was so traumatised after the birth that she couldnrsquot go to a maternity ward to visit her best friend and baby. Jamie went but lsquoa feeling of dread descended on me. You see things, like the number on the door, and itrsquos like flashbacksrsquo.The McCallums kept each other afloat those first few months - when one was down, the other was up. Victoria recalls crying as she breastfed Rosie and wonderingshe was in the middle of a lsquogrief cyclersquo and lsquoletting go of the child I expected to haversquo.She spent lsquothe first eight weeks of Rosiersquos le trying to figure outI wanted to keep herrsquo. Victoriarsquos voice falters and her eyes fill as she talks about how her sisters find that hard to believe because she was so protective of Rosie lsquofrom the moment she was bornrsquo.At one point, Jamie tried to rationalise what had happened by thinking of Rosie as a pet. Theyrsquore both shocked at the thoughts which went through their minds.Unlike many children with Downrsquos Syndrome, Rosie had no severe health problems, such as a congenital heart condition, so there was little dference raising Rosie to any other baby.Slowly, the couple began to think lsquowait a minute, why is this meant to be so bad rsquo. There was lsquono Hollywood momentrsquo, says Jamie, when things went from dark to light, but he recalls feeding Rosie one day when she was six months and apologising to her aloud. lsquoAt that point I believed it would be okay,rsquo he says, lsquoand thatrsquos a major hurdlersquo.Things changed for Victoria when she thought about adoption, but couldnrsquot imagine anyone caring for Rosie the way she could. She recalls going to a Downrsquos Syndrome meeting and realising lsquoI just want to be her mumrsquo.The mundane reality is that le with Downrsquos Syndrome just takes a little bit longer. Children will learn to read, walk, talk, go to the toilet, feed themselves - just like any other child - but theyrsquoll always be a little slower. Rosie is probably a year behind other children.Children with Downrsquos Syndrome learn dferently too. Theyrsquore more perceptive of emotions, and visual learners, says Jamie, so they identy the physical shapes of words quicker than sounds - thatrsquos why their house is plastered with stickers on furniture and appliances marked lsquoovenrsquo, lsquotable, lsquochairrsquo. They also use sign language to speed up Rosiersquos acquisition of speech.Rosie is in pre-school and about to go into Primary One. Children like her in mainstream education help eliminate prejudice. Unlike their parents, the children in Rosiersquos class have grown up with a friend with Downrsquos Syndrome and are basically blind to her condition. lsquoI can see the positive effects of Rosie on other people,rsquo says Jamie.Hersquos jealous of Rosiersquos classmates. lsquoWersquove created a society that values material things - cars, money - and these kids will grow up with someone who isnrsquot driven by that, and lives in the now, all the time, and her driving force is to be happy.rsquoVictoria adds: lsquoPeople say itrsquos changed their way of thinking, just being part of her le. She teaches us more than we could ever teach her. She teaches us to be far, far better human beings, and just be happier people.rsquoRosie and a bunch of other children with Downrsquos Syndrome touched the world this time last year when a viral video of the kids and their mums lip-synching and hand-signing a carpool karaoke version of Christina Perrirsquos lsquoA Thousand Yearsrsquo clocked  million views. Perri contacted them saying shersquod cried over the film - her song ed to the top five. It made national news in  countries, and Victoria and other mums appeared on This Morning. Michael Bubleacute got involved when the children covered lsquoAll I want for Christmasrsquo. The McCallums started the charity lsquoWouldnrsquot Change A Thingrsquo, celebrating children like Rosie, and aimed at correcting those misconceptions which caused them so much grief when she was born.Jamie says in the past hersquos told people that Downrsquos Syndrome lsquoisnrsquot as bad as you think, but now Irsquove actually come to believe that therersquos serious benefits to this - like the effect on others, like the positive effect on your own values. It makes you a better personrsquo.lsquoThe paradox is,rsquo adds Jamie, lsquothat therersquos been this major progress in understanding how they learn, major medical progress too, and thatrsquos happening simultaneously with the progress in screening and termination to the point of almost eradication. So just as yoursquove kind of cracked it on one side, therersquoll be none of them left.rsquoThe idea of there one day being no more people with Downrsquos Syndrome chills them, thinking of what would be lost. lsquoYou see beyond peoplersquos disabilities to the soul behind that, you see the person,rsquo says Victoria. lsquoThatrsquos what Rosie has taught me.rsquoJamie and Victoria treat Rosie no dferently to their other children, Abigail and Gregor - and she can get in just as much trouble as them. The McCallums expect a full le for Rosie - job, travel, love.lsquoWhen we first had Rosie,rsquo says Victoria, lsquoI was very scared that wersquod have her for the rest of our lives, but actually Rosiersquos biggest problem about leaving this house is going to be me not wanting her to go. I think the first child out the door will be her - shersquos the most independent. Irsquom not scared for her future now in any way whatsoever.rsquoWHEN WORDS CUT AS DEEP AS WOUNDSWHILE so much has changed for the better in society when it comes to the lives of people with Downrsquos Syndrome, language is still a blight. Words hurt.Jo Hughes helps run the charity Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland . It may surprise some, she says, but lsquoyou still hear people with Downrsquos Syndrome referred to as mongolsrsquo.Mistakes are also made by people not meaning to be cruel. Often the terms lsquoDownrsquos Syndrome personrsquo or a lsquoDownrsquos personrsquo is used - thatrsquos putting the disability before the human being. DSS has started a new lsquoMind Your Languagersquo campaign for Downrsquos Syndrome Week to let people know that the accepted term is lsquoa person with Downrsquos Syndromersquo.While years ago, negative misconceptions hurt, today seemingly positive misconceptions can do damage too. lsquoTherersquos a huge misconception out there that all people with Downrsquos Syndrome are forever smiley and happy,rsquo says Hughes, who worries about this lsquochildlikersquo image being thrust on the entire community. lsquoThey have the same range of emotions and feelings as every other human being.rsquo They go through puberty just like other teenagers, and can be stroppy adolescents.For Hughes, the struggle to change language is personal. Her son Jack, , has Downrsquos Syndrome and she wants him to enjoy lsquothe best le he can haversquo.Changing language, changes how people are seen, she says. lsquoFor every person who we can change how they think and talk about Downrsquos Syndrome, thatrsquos another day thatrsquos been worth going to work.rsquoSTUDENT AND SWIMMING CHAMP - JUST AN AVERAGE GIRL FROM AYRCERYS McCrindle is the future. Aged just , shersquos getting ready to leave mainstream school in Ayr after taking her National Fours in English, Maths, French, Art, Home Economics and Admin. She plans to go on to sixth year and then study beauty therapy at college.But working professionally in swimming is her real ambition. Three years ago, she joined the GB team for people with Downrsquos Syndrome, and has so far won three silvers at the Special Olympics, gold and silver at the European Championships, and bronze at the world championships.Cerysrsquo success fills her mother Karen, father Ewan and brother Lewis with pride. lsquoWersquove treated Cerys just the same as any other child since she was born,rsquo says Karen. The world is more accepting these days, but there can still be some stupid comments at school - usually from boys. Cerys lsquotells them to grow up and answers them backrsquo, her mother says. Closed minds are a minority among young people, though, and school has been a positive experience.What worries Karen most is that while the younger generation has changed, the older generation retains old-fashioned prejudices - and that might damage Cerys when it comes to employment.lsquoWersquore now coming out of the comfort zone,rsquo says Karen, adding: lsquoShersquos getting to leaving school age. Evenshe does have a full CV, is there someone whorsquod look and think lsquoDownrsquos Syndrome, whatrsquos she going to offerrsquo hellip Therersquos a fear that no-one will give her a chance.rsquo

title: one-visitor-set-aside-15m-for-a-three-day-highlands-tour
story: Scotlandrsquos new breed of high-rolling visitors may be here on holiday but most of us wonrsquot see them ndash for these are not your typical Royal Mile tourists.Instead, some of the worldrsquos wealthiest people are pouring millions into hiring castles to stay in, chartering yachts and helicopters to whisk them from distilleries to golf courses, and private dinners with lairds and lords demanding unique experiences that, it turns out, money really can buy.Scotland is in the midst of a luxury holiday boom, and attracting rising numbers of enormously wealthy visitors desperate to indulge in adventures that most Scots would never imagine.The sums of money involved can be eye-watering. One case Chinese visitor is said to have set aside pound. million for a three-day tour of the Highlands.While that is at the extreme end of the scale, insiders say itrsquos not unusual for ldquoaverage visitors to spend pound, per person for a week, while others can easily spend double that on a single shopping spree at the House of Bruar.One luxury tour operator said: ldquoThe sky is the limit. A lot of whatrsquos going on is very discreet ndash most people donrsquot realise the amount of money flowing through the country.In many cases the millionaire tourist is looking to pay top dollar to share a dram with a whisky expert, play golf on a remote Hebridean course that most Scots have never heard of, or join scallop ers and fishermen off the west coast, rather than rub shoulders with the hoi polloi at the usual tourist haunts.According to a report from Allied Market Research, the global luxury market is projected to be the fastest-growing area of the tourism sector, expected to be worth ,bn by .A key element is said to be demand from high-end travellers to gain deeper experiences of the places they visit, avoiding tourist hotspots in favour of highly-personalised trips.VisitScotland has suggested income from ldquohigh-net-worth iniduals is forecast to rise by around % a year. Chief executive Malcolm Roughead said: ldquoIt is important that we encourage the tourism industry to provide world-class service, facilities, events and attractions to keep up with ever-changing consumer demands and ensure visitors continue to have memorable experiences.While luxury tour operators have always had a place in Scotlandrsquos tourist sector, there are signs of a growing response to rising demand, from hotels offering bespoke packages, to firms specialising in personalised itineraries and road trip specialists who send tourists off in Aston Martins to tackle the North Coast  ndash at around pound, a pop.Last week, five-star Edinburgh hotel The Glasshouse became the latest to join the luxury ldquoexperience market with a two-night Elite Whisky Experience ndash costing pound, a head.That buys two nights for two people at the hotelrsquos lavish Islay Suite overlooking Calton Hill, meals ndash including a seven-course whisky tasting dinner ndash guided tour of a distillery and the chance to explore the hotelrsquos selection of  whiskies with its whisky ambassador on hand to help with selections.One company, Bravo Whisky Golf, which specialises in tailor-made golf packages which whisk visitors from course to course by chartered plane, is offering three nights in an Islay hotel and chartered plane to watch this yearrsquos Open at Royal Portrush, plus a distillery tour and a round at Machrie Golf Links ndash for around pound,.ldquoTypically, clients will spend , to , per head for golf, accommodation, flights, meals and drinks, said Neil Scott Johnson, who co-founded Bravo Whisky Golf with his friend Paul Geddes. ldquoThese people have done Carnoustie, St Andrews and Turnberry and are looking for new experiences. They want to get home and say lsquoThe plane landed on this island beach and we played an amazing Old Tom Morris links coursersquo.Among its tours is a -day ldquoOdyssey involving  flights and  golf courses ndash mostly on Hebridean islands or in the Highlands. Thrown in is dinner with a whisky aficionado and an evening on board the former royal yacht Britannia.Wealthy visitors swoop into the country on board private jets and book up entire country houses or castles for their party at eye-watering costs, says Simeon Rosset, who runs Rosset Bespoke Butlers and is often called on to arrange high-end accommodation and staff for well-heeled visitors.ldquoYou would never recognise them ndash theyrsquore not travelling around in Rolls-Royces, theyrsquore not that obvious. But they will go out on shopping trips to the House of Bruar and spend pound,, he said. ldquoTherersquos huge money travelling through Scotland. A group of  staying for a week can easily spend poundm.If anything, he adds, there is a shortage of luxury produce for them to spend their money on. ldquoThis is high-level tourism and we need to persuade people to join in and provide what they want, he said.Specialist companies like Edinburgh-based Dream Escape promise ldquoluxurious private cruises to exclusive access to historic castles and other elegant accommodation combined with Michelin-star dining, with chauffeur-driven tours, adventure activities and private helicopters.However, as well as the established players and the London-based high-end agencies, a new breed of ldquograss-roots operators is also finding a niche within a massively wealthy market.Chris Hunter of Luxury Concierge Scotland was running a chauffeur business when he spotted demand from wealthy visitors seeking ldquosomething dferent.He now organises bespoke tours, arranging castle accommodation, supercars for hitting the North Coast  and gourmet dining.ldquoI have a couple coming in June who want to tour in a car, so Irsquom organising a Porsche  for them. They want to stay in a castle on the west coast, and then therersquos the obligatory helicopter tour, so theyrsquoll go from the castle over to Skye for a distillery visit, he said.ldquoThese are people who can do spas and luxury hotels anywhere. What they want in Scotland are those experiences they canrsquot get anywhere .French-born Solveig Kerdranvat and her fianceacute Jonny Stage are the modern face of luxury travel in Scotland ndash images on their Sandgrouse website show her posing in a kilt gazing at island moorland, or ldquohunting-shooting style beside a Land Rover.The helicopter they use to ferry their clients on ldquodistillery crawls ndash involving stops at multiple distilleries across Scotland in a single day ndash features a familiar registration, G-TRMP, and was once used by Donald Trump.Sandgrouse tours can hit pound, per person, while some special requests can prove particularly demanding.ldquoPeople are looking out-of-the-box experiences, says Mr Stage. ldquoFor example, we take them to the Glenfinnan viaduct at just the right time to see the steam train passing. So theyrsquore hovering above it rather than standing in the car park with everyone .Wealthy tourists want to be able to impress their friends by doing something unique, he adds.ldquoThey want to come to Scotland and be best buddies with the fishermen on the west coast, or have a great day ing for scallops or with a ghillie whorsquos been on an estate for  years.ldquoThen they go back to New York and talk about an amazing day with a guy on the hill who showed them the stags.ldquoThatrsquos what luxury travel is about.TIE PIECEA recovering global economy is fuelling a worldwide luxury travel sector currently said to be worth  billionn.However, Scotland is hardly a new destination for the worldrsquos super rich ndash after all, the Queen made a point of spending her summer break cruising the west coast in Britannia and staying at Balmoral, while Skibo Castle near Dornoch has been a retreat for the rich for decades.Two years ago, Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich took a west coast break when he moored his super yacht, Eclipse, in the Clyde.Last year, billionaire mathematician James Simons parked his pound million super yacht at ious locations during a summer tour of Scotland. His net worth is estimated at poundbn.Meanwhile, some of the richest people in the world have opted to create a more permanent holiday home.The billionaire ruler of Dubai, Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid al-Maktoum, has taken over a ,-acre holiday estate in Inverinate, Wester Ross, and Russian drinks billionaire Yuri Shefler bought Tulchan Estate ndash a ,-acre property  miles south of Inverness said to boast some of the best salmon fishing in Europe.

title: from-eco-homes-to-utopia
story: Early th-century middle-class housing was spacious and comfortable, with the influence of the Arts And Crafts movement and the advent of domestic electricity creating an appetite for tasteful interiors and state-of-the-art household gadgets.It was in this climate of genteel consumerism that the Ideal Home Exhibition was born.
